channel.name: Node Worker:  Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'memory')

messages.content:
I try to compile/run circuit by **Node Worker**(worker_thread),  sample & error like the pics.  

I found similar issue at https://github.com/o1-labs/snarkyjs/issues/995,  But cannot find out the solution for **Node Worker**.

embeds.title: Issues · o1-labs/snarkyjs
embeds.description: TypeScript framework for zk-SNARKs and zkApps. Contribute to o1-labs/snarkyjs development by creating an account on GitHub.

messages.content: hi,  @gregor @Florian  , would u pls share me any suggestions??
I remember this problem. It's a limitation of how the snarkyjs node worker code works. It assumes that it's run on the main thread
So we will need to fix snarkyjs to make this work
ok! thx!
For what it's worth, I also see a similar error when trying to run snarkyjs on the main thread in a Deno program:
`error: Uncaught (in worker "$DENO_STD_NODE_WORKER_THREAD") TypeError: Cannot read properties of null (reading 'memory')`

Error:

```console
/home/chrlyz/wrdhom_server/node_modules/o1js/dist/node/bindings/compiled/_node_bindings/snarky_js_node.bc.cjs:6815
         throw err;
         ^
Error [LinkError]: WebAssembly.Instance(): Import #0 module="env" function="memory" error: memory import must be a WebAssembly.Memory object
    at Object.<anonymous> (/home/chrlyz/wrdhom_server/node_modules/o1js/dist/node/bindings/compiled/_node_bindings/plonk_wasm.cjs:9828:22)
    at Module._compile (node:internal/modules/cjs/loader:1256:14)
    at Module._extensions..js (node:internal/modules/cjs/loader:1310:10)
    at Module.load (node:internal/modules/cjs/loader:1119:32)
    at Module._load (node:internal/modules/cjs/loader:960:12)
    at ModuleWrap.<anonymous> (node:internal/modules/esm/translators:169:29)
    at ModuleJob.run (node:internal/modules/esm/module_job:194:25)
Emitted 'error' event on Worker instance at:
    at [kOnErrorMessage] (node:internal/worker:300:10)
    at [kOnMessage] (node:internal/worker:311:37)
    at MessagePort.<anonymous> (node:internal/worker:212:57)
    at [nodejs.internal.kHybridDispatch] (node:internal/event_target:741:20)
    at exports.emitMessage (node:internal/per_context/messageport:23:28)

Node.js v18.17.1
```

Update:

If you are trying to parallelize proof generation, you would likely need to use the `SandboxedJob` feature from `bullqm`, since the regular jobs like in my example, seem to share threads, throwing the error:

```console
Error: It seems you're running multiple provers concurrently within the same JavaScript thread, which, at the moment, is not supported and would lead to bugs.
    at QueueEvents.onFailed (/home/chrlyz/wrdhom_server/node_modules/bullmq/dist/cjs/classes/job.js:634:24)
    at QueueEvents.emit (node:events:514:28)
    at QueueEvents.emit (/home/chrlyz/wrdhom_server/node_modules/bullmq/dist/cjs/classes/queue-base.js:82:26)
    at QueueEvents.emit (/home/chrlyz/wrdhom_server/node_modules/bullmq/dist/cjs/classes/queue-events.js:29:22)
    at QueueEvents.consumeEvents (/home/chrlyz/wrdhom_server/node_modules/bullmq/dist/cjs/classes/queue-events.js:101:30)
    at process.processTicksAndRejections (node:internal/process/task_queues:95:5)
    at async QueueEvents.run (/home/chrlyz/wrdhom_server/node_modules/bullmq/dist/cjs/classes/queue-events.js:60:17)

Node.js v18.17.1
```

But I'm having some issues trying to use `SandboxedJob` in my project. See:
https://github.com/taskforcesh/bullmq/issues/1698

messages.content: For parallel processing, you can also consider the backend. In my project, I can now calculate 32 proofs in parallel and merge them in parallel. Each proof requires 4 GB of memory for calculation, so it is a total of 128 GB being used simultaneously, and it can be increased with a small effort to 128 or 256 proofs. The prover keys are cached in EFS and available immediately for use.
Interesting, but what do you mean by the backend? 👀

Under the hood is AWS lambda, EFS for prover keys, DynamoDB for sequencer state storage, and S3 for contract code/prover keys uploading
https://discord.com/channels/484437221055922177/1179482557549662249/1181150533164216371

Mmm... It looks like there you are solving the issue of avoiding recompiling across different machines, right? How are you managing the execution of the programs that generate those proofs? Do you have an example from the point where you start the generation of those proofs and then use them?

Yes, you can look into 
https://github.com/dfstio/minanft-api/blob/master/api.ts
https://github.com/dfstio/minanft-api/blob/master/sequencer.ts
https://github.com/dfstio/minanft-api/blob/master/src/api/sequencer.ts

But maybe the more straightforward way will be to try. I can give you the endpoint to call, like
```
    const apiresult = await minanft.tree({
      transactions,
      task: "proof",
      arguments: [height.toString()],
    });
```
where transactions are the string array, and I will need your ZkProgram code that
- Takes a string as an argument and computes the proof, returns proof as a string
- Takes two strings with proofs as arguments, calculates merged proof, and returns merged proof as a string.
The example: https://github.com/dfstio/minanft-api/blob/master/src/api/steptree.ts

Backend will return the final merged proof to you as soon as it will be ready:
```
const result = await minanft.tree_result({ jobId : apiresult.jobId });
```
The test: https://github.com/dfstio/minanft-lib/blob/master/tests/redactedtree.api.test.ts
Thanks for the response. I'll look into it 👀
Or you can write your chain with Protokit, and we'll do the proving in paralel for you as well 🙂

Haha, maybe I should try Protokit already. Although the lack of documentation is one of the things that prevents me to do so. Having a quick reference to everything about a framework is important to me. I also want to avoid to abstract things too early, because I like to understand how things work under the hood and maintain flexibility and minimize dependencies. But maybe I have struggled enough to appreciate Protokit more and start using it 😆 

Just a few questions:

I see that Protokit uses BullMQ for its workers, but it doesn't use `SandboxedJob` jobs. Doesn't this causes issues while running the o1js provers in parallel?

Can Protokit process my proofs in parallel, even if they depend on certain order? For example, if I want to generate proofs for the 3 firsts posts on my platform from 3 different users, I order them, assigning post number 1, 2, 3 to each post, and userPostsNumber 1, 1, 1. The global counter is just one of the 8 fields in the smart contract, which is added 1 by each post, while the counter for posts of individual users is a Merkle Map where the leave store the counter for each user. The state of each post is hashed and stored on another Merkle Map. But to generate a proof to update the state of the smart contract for each post in parallel, then I need to calculate the state transitions in certain order for the posts and then use these calculations as inputs fo the zkProgram that generates their proofs. Then to merge the proofs I also need to merge them in certain order. Can I do this on Protokit?
you dont need to do this in Protokit, any state in runtime modules can be modified sequentially, no need for custom circuit architectures
What I don't need to do?
create custom circuit architectures to make your app work
let alone think about 8 fields in the zk app, or working with multiple trees, none of this is necessary anymore
also what you described as ‘state transition’ is how Protokit works under the hood, but you dont have to worry about that at all, same as if you were writing in eg EVM
If I don't have to worry about the number of fields, how for example I know how much I even need to pay to update the on-chain state of my application?
for the l1 contract, there’s barely any state stored - just the root hash of the underlying l2 state tree
Oh, ok, I thought the L2 was just for the processing, and my contracts would live on Mina
i’d suggest revisiting the workshop: https://youtu.be/hqobPb3gIRo?si=QK_Ntv5O5-XlNr0o

embeds.title: Introduction to Protokit - Protocol development framework for priva...
embeds.description: Protokit enables developers to build zero-knowledge, interoperable and privacy preserving application chains with a minimal learning curve. This workshop walks through the basics of zero-knowledge proofs, and explains techniques

messages.content: But then I also get different finality and security guarantees than creating my own circuits over native Mina zkApps, right?
no, the security guarantees are more or less inherited from the L1, as you eventually may also use sequence state as a mempool, while also using the l1 for settlement
Fair enough
I still wonder, how does Protokit executes proof generation in parallel using BullMQ without SandboxedJob jobs, @maht0rz 🤔
our block production pipeline is designed with sandbox workers in mind, not as in sandboxed jobs like bullmq describes. but as in running them even on entirely separate machines
we will be enabling proving mode in the coming weeks, right now the entire pipeline runs with proofsEnabled: false

if there’ll be a setup where there’ll be multiple workers running in the same JS process, we might end up having to enable sandboxed jobs too. But its just a small configuration in the grand scheme of things
That's discouraging, since proof generation is the core of all of this

Update:

It seems like they fixed the `SandboxedJob` issue in BullMQ I reported  🚀
i dont see whats discouraging about it, the whole pipeline runs as it would in-prover, but runs simulated out of the prover instead
In the sense that proof generations in the framework hasn't been tested enough

Also my current code actually generates the proofs and updates the on-chain state. Delivering something for Cohort 2 that just in theory eventually would generate the proofs, would feel like a setback

Yeah, it seems like running every worker on its own machine for proof generation is the right approach, since each proof generation uses all the computational power available, so running more than one worker on the same machine would basically behave like generating the proofs sequentially. This is the kind of things I like to learn by sometimes choosing doing things the hard way 😋 

I hope not to come off as dismissive about the work you guys are doing with Protokit. It's just that it may not be a good fit for how I'm thinking about my project (at least at the moment). Going back to the security guarantees for example, if I understand correctly, using Protokit, the root state of an application lives on the L2, so that's a security trade-off (it may be cheaper and maybe eventually that's exactly what my project needs, but a trade-off after all). Plus there are some more questions, like how proofs are processed by the L2, how decentralized the L2 will be, finality, composability, flexibility, etc.

Another worry would be marrying your project to an L2 at a very early stage.
Hi @chrlyz I'm from the future :D I'm trying to do the same thing, have you found a good solution for this?

If I remember correctly, the issue here was trying to run more than 1 worker in the same machine to create proofs, which doesn't really makes much sense, since creating a single proof will use most of the resources of the machine it is running on, so what you need to do is running each worker in its own machine
